Name: Caspian Sea
Notes: Geologically a small ocean rather than a lake. Garabogazköl lagoon, if counted separately, would rank as the world's 15th largest, with an area of 18,000 square kilometres (6,900 sq mi).

Name: Superior
Notes: Largest of the Great Lakes by volume, having more water than the other four combined.[15]

Name: Victoria
Notes: The largest lake by area in Africa.[16]

Name: Huron
Notes: The larger lobe of Lake Michigan–Huron. Contains Manitoulin Island, the world's largest lake island.[17]

Name: Michigan
Notes: The smaller lobe of Lake Michigan–Huron. The largest lake (by area) that is located entirely in one country.

Name: Tanganyika
Countries with shoreline: Tanzania Democratic Republic of the Congo Burundi Zambia
Notes: Longest freshwater lake in the world and third largest of any kind by volume.[18]

Name: Baikal
Notes: Deepest lake in the world and largest freshwater lake in the world by volume.[19]

Name: Great Bear Lake
Notes: Largest lake entirely within Canada,[20] and the largest lake partially within the Arctic Circle

Name: Malawi
Notes: Has more species of fish than any other lake in the world.[21]

Name: Great Slave Lake
Notes: Deepest lake in North America[22]

Name: Erie
Notes: Has the smallest volume of the Great Lakes.

Name: Winnipeg
Notes: Very large catchment area compared to own size. No other great lake has that ratio.

Name: Ontario
Notes: The lowest lying of the Great Lakes.

Name: Ladoga
Notes: Largest lake in Europe.[23]

Name: Balkhash
Notes: Fresh shallow western part. Salty deeper eastern part. Shrinking in size.

Name: Vostok
Notes: Largest lake in Antarctica, but subglacial.

Name: Onega
Notes: Second-largest lake in Europe.

Name: Titicaca
Notes: Highest navigable lake in the world. Greatest mountain lake too. Largest lake in South America.

Name: Nicaragua
Notes: Largest lake in Central America. Contains fresh water sharks.

Name: Athabasca
Notes: A remnant of the vast, Glacial Lake McConnell. Huge catchment area (ratio).

Name: Reindeer
Notes: The deepest areas are the site of a large meteorite impact, which happened almost 100 million years ago. Much older than the lake.

Name: Turkana
Notes: Largest permanent desert lake and the world's largest alkaline lake.[24]

Name: Issyk-Kul
Notes: Second largest mountain lake in the world. Second deepest saline lake as well.

Name: Vänern
Notes: Largest lake in the European Union.

Name: Rukwa
Notes: Tanzania's 4th largest lake.

Name: Albert
Countries with shoreline: Uganda  Democratic Republic of the Congo

Name: Nettilling
Notes: Largest lake on an island; Baffin Island.[27]

Name: Winnipegosis
Notes: Second largest lake in Manitoba.

Name: Mweru
Countries with shoreline: Zambia  Democratic Republic of the Congo
Notes: The second largest lake in the Congo's drainage basin, Tanganyika being the largest.

Name: Nipigon
Notes: Largest lake entirely in Ontario. Part of the Great Lake drainage basin. Often referred to as the, "sixth" or "seventh" lake, together with St. Clair.

Name: Manitoba
Notes: A remnant of the prehistoric, Glacial Lake Agassiz together with: Winnipeg and Winnipegosis.

Name: Taymyr
Notes: Largest lake entirely within the Arctic Circle.

Name: Qinghai
Notes: Largest lake in China. Variable in size. Endorheic basin.

Name: Saimaa
Notes: Largest catchment area of the lakes within the Nordic countries.

Name: Lake of the Woods
Notes: About 15 000 islands. The shoreline measures (included these) roughly: 105 000 km.

Name: Khanka
Notes: Has a shape like a pear. Variable size. Drains through the Amur River, that ends in the Sea of Japan.

Name: Sarygamysh
Notes: Located about midway between the Caspian Endorheic basin and former Aral Sea. No drainage river today. Drained centuries ago to the Caspian Sea (Uzboy River). Polluted.

Name: Dubawnt
Notes: Frozen surface 10 months each year. No permanent settlements on its shores.

Name: Van
Notes: Largest lake in the Middle East. Third deepest saline lake.

Name: Peipus
Notes: Largest trans-boundary lake in Europe.

Name: Uvs
Notes: Greatest lake in Mongolia (by area). Very large catchment area (endorheic).

Name: North Aral Sea
Notes: Largest remnant of the former Aral Sea. Once the world's third largest lake.

Name: Poyang
Notes: Largest fresh water lake in China. Variable size. Important location for the birdlife.

Name: Tana
Notes: The source of the Blue Nile.

Name: Amadjuak
Notes: In geological terms, a "young" lake (approximately 4,500 years old). Second largest on Baffin Island, third largest in Nunavut.

Name: Melville
Type: Saline 1.95% (approx. average of surface and bottom water)
Notes: Estuary connected with the Atlantic Ocean. Large drainage basin in the Labrador.

Name: Bangweulu
Notes: One of the world's great wetland systems. The area has swamps and floodplain. Variable size on this shallow lake. Crucial importance for animals and birds, of a far larger area.
